results.title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
results.abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

results.title: Siblings Fight Over Estate of Mother Whose Land Yielded a T. Rex Skeleton
results.abstract: The skeleton, which was found on a ranch in South Dakota in 1990 and later sold for more than $8 million, has been the subject of numerous legal challenges.
results.byline: By Lola Fadulu and Michael Levenson

multimedia.caption: Garth Dallman, center, and Bill Kouchie, right, of the dinosaur restoration firm Research Casting International, Ltd., begin dismantling Sue, the Tyrannosaurus rex, at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago in 2018.

results.title: Fate of Billions for Opioid Victims From Sacklers Rests With Supreme Court
results.abstract: The court will decide whether Purdue’s owners can gain permanent immunity from future opioid lawsuits in exchange for payments up to $6 billion.

multimedia.caption: From left: Tiffinee Scott, Dede Yoder and Cheryl Juaire, whose children became addicted to the Purdue painkiller OxyContin and later died, wrote to the Supreme Court.
multimedia.copyright: Hilary Swift for The New York Times

results.title: What to Know About Home Care Services
results.abstract: Finding an aide to help an older person stay at home safely takes work. Here’s a guide.
results.kicker: Dying Broke: The High Cost of help

results.title: Desperate Families Search for Affordable Home Care
results.abstract: Facing a severe shortage of aides and high costs, people trying to keep aging loved ones at home often cobble together a patchwork of family and friends to help.
results.byline: By Reed Abelson and Desiree Rios
results.kicker: dying broke: The High Cost of Help

results.title: Biden Administration Unleashes Powerful Regulatory Tool Aimed at Climate
results.abstract: Its new estimate of the economic impact of climate change could create the legal justification for aggressive new regulations.
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

multimedia.caption: Tucked in its new rules to curb methane emissions, the E.P.A. set a new social cost for carbon, a number almost four times its previous amount: $190 a ton.
Tucked in its new rules to curb methane emissions, the E.P.A. set a new social cost for carbon, a number almost four times its previous amount: $190 a ton.

results.title: Scientists in Discredited Alcohol Study Will Not Advise U.S. on Drinking Guidelines
results.abstract: Two researchers with ties to beer and liquor companies had been named to a panel that will review the health evidence on alcohol consumption. But after a New York Times story was published, the panel’s organizers decided to drop them.
org_facet: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine
National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

multimedia.caption: Although alcohol, and particularly red wine, has long enjoyed a health halo, more rigorous recent research and concerns about industry bias have raised doubts about its health benefits.
Although alcohol, and particularly red wine, has long enjoyed a health halo, more rigorous recent research and concerns about industry bias have raised doubts about its health benefits.
Although alcohol, and particularly red wine, has long enjoyed a health halo, more rigorous recent research and concerns about industry bias have raised doubts about its health benefits.

results.title: U.S. Health Officials Push Back on Idea of New Virus in China
results.abstract: A surge of children has been hospitalized in China for respiratory illnesses, but international health authorities said the cause was common viruses and bacteria.
results.byline: By Benjamin Mueller and Emily Baumgaertner

multimedia.caption: The waiting room of a children’s hospital in Beijing last month. Experts say there are no signs of a threatening new pathogen.
The waiting room of a children’s hospital in Beijing last month. Experts say there are no signs of a threatening new pathogen.
The waiting room of a children’s hospital in Beijing last month. Experts say there are no signs of a threatening new pathogen.

results.title: U.S. Rate of Suicide by Firearm Reaches Record Level
results.abstract: Gun suicides increased from prepandemic rates in all racial and ethnic groups, but the degree of change differed drastically.

results.title: Brain Study Suggests Traumatic Memories Are Processed as Present Experience
results.abstract: Traumatic memories had their own neural mechanism, brain scans showed, which may help explain their vivid and intrusive nature.

multimedia.caption: An M.R.I. scan of a brain highlighting the posterior cingulate cortex. In a study, traumatic memories appeared to engage this area, which is usually involved in internally directed thought, like introspection or daydreaming.

An M.R.I. scan of a brain highlighting the posterior cingulate cortex. In a study, traumatic memories appeared to engage this area, which is usually involved in internally directed thought, like introspection or daydreaming.

results.title: Climate Change Drives New Cases of Malaria, Complicating Efforts to Fight the Disease
results.abstract: The number of malaria cases rose again in 2022, propelled by flooding and warmer weather in areas once free of the illness.

multimedia.caption: A doctor tended to a malaria patient affected by flooding in a hospital in Sehwan, Pakistan, last year.
A doctor tended to a malaria patient affected by flooding in a hospital in Sehwan, Pakistan, last year.

results.title: A Climate Summit Begins With Fossil Fuels, and Frustration, Going Strong
results.abstract: After decades of meetings, nations still haven’t agreed to curb the main driver of global warming.

multimedia.caption: Preparations underway for the opening of the United Nations Climate Summit in Dubai on Wednesday.

results.title: Where the World Is (and Isn’t) Making Progress on Climate Change
results.abstract: Emissions from electricity and transportation are projected to fall over time, a new report finds, but industry remains a major climate challenge.
results.byline: By Brad Plumer and Nadja Popovich
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

results.title: ¿Un medicamento para que tu perro viva más?

results.title: U.S. Life Expectancy Creeps Up as Covid Deaths Fall
results.abstract: But the country’s health has not fully rebounded from the pandemic, according to new data from the C.D.C.
results.byline: By Emily Anthes and Benjamin Mueller
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: In 2022, life expectancy at birth was 77.5 years, compared with 76.4 years in 2021, the C.D.C. calculated.

results.title: Wolverines Get Protection in the Lower 48 States
results.abstract: Officials will add the predators, threatened by climate change and habitat loss in much of the United States, to the Endangered Species List.

multimedia.caption: An estimated 300 wolverines remain in the lower 48, in parts of the northern Rocky Mountains and northern Cascades in Montana, Idaho, Wyoming and Washington.
An estimated 300 wolverines remain in the lower 48, in parts of the northern Rocky Mountains and northern Cascades in Montana, Idaho, Wyoming and Washington.

results.title: This Seed Season, Consider a Catalog That Takes a Different Approach
results.abstract: At Turtle Tree Seed, adults with developmental differences work “side by side” with other staff to produce seed that’s more artisanal than agribusiness.

multimedia.caption: Turtle Tree Seed is part of Camphill Village Copake, an intentional community of adults with developmental differences. Tasks are broken down into component parts so that all can contribute, whatever their abilities.

results.title: Innovative Cancer Treatment May Sometimes Cause Cancer, F.D.A. Says
results.abstract: The agency is looking into reports that some patients developed new blood cancers after receiving CAR-T treatments.

multimedia.caption: A composite colored scanning electron micrograph of T cells, blue, and a lymphoma cancer cell, red.

results.title: Popular Science Shuts Online Magazine in Another Sign of Decline
results.abstract: The decision came three years after the publication ended its storied print edition, which began in 1872. It will still publish articles and videos on its website.

multimedia.caption: Popular Science was “very beautiful, very historical” and “a real treasure of American popular intellectual publishing,” a former editor in chief of the publication said.
Popular Science was “very beautiful, very historical” and “a real treasure of American popular intellectual publishing,” a former editor in chief of the publication said.

results.title: Files Suggest Climate Summit’s Leader Is Using Event to Promote Fossil Fuels
results.abstract: A leaked document has talking points for the president of the United Nations climate conference, who is an oil executive in the United Arab Emirates, to advance oil and gas deals.

results.title: Will Dyeing the Connecticut River Help Keep It Alive?
results.abstract: Hydrilla, a rapidly spreading invasive plant, is choking New England’s longest river. Government scientists are fighting back.

multimedia.caption: An unusually aggressive strain of hydrilla is clogging a 70-mile stretch of the Connecticut River. Scientists fear it will spread more widely.

results.title: Egypt Wiped Out Hepatitis C. Now It Is Trying to Help the Rest of Africa.
results.abstract: Effective drugs that have made the disease curable have yet to reach most  of the region.
results.byline: By Stephanie Nolen and Natalija Gormalova

results.title: Biden’s Absence at Climate Summit Highlights His Fossil Fuel Conundrum

results.title: Former Coal Towns Get Money for Clean-Energy Factories
results.abstract: An Energy Department program designed to create jobs and manufacturing in communities reliant on fossil fuels is backing projects in West Virginia, Colorado and elsewhere.

results.title: Biden to Skip U.N. Climate Summit, White House Official Says
results.abstract: He has attended the past two summits and calls climate change “the ultimate threat” but will miss the talks that are set to begin in Dubai on Thursday.
results.byline: By Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley
des_facet: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

multimedia.caption: Senior White House aides have said the president has been consumed by trying to secure a pause in the war between Israel and Hamas and release of hostages held by Hamas.

results.title: Unvaccinated and Vulnerable: Children Drive Surge in Deadly Outbreaks
results.abstract: About 60 million “zero-dose children” have not received any vaccines and have aged out of routine immunization programs. Protecting them will require a costly vaccination blitz.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
